metadata.sources: Approximated from DrugBank, FDA labels, Lexicomp, clinical pharmacology references

interactions.notes: Fluoxetine strongly inhibits CYP2D6 (tramadol activation) and both increase serotonergic activity. Risk of serotonin syndrome.
Dual SSRI use: extreme serotonin syndrome risk. No clinical rationale for combining.
Dual SSRI use with overlapping CYP2D6 inhibition.
Dual SSRI use plus additive QT prolongation risk from citalopram.
Fluoxetine strongly inhibits CYP2D6, blocking codeine conversion to morphine. Loss of analgesic effect.
Fentanyl has serotonergic activity. Combined with SSRI increases serotonin syndrome risk.
Fluoxetine inhibits CYP2D6, increasing metoprolol levels. May cause excessive bradycardia and hypotension.
Fluoxetine inhibits CYP2C9 and may displace warfarin from protein binding. Increased bleeding risk.
Fluoxetine may inhibit carbamazepine metabolism, while carbamazepine induces fluoxetine metabolism.
Fluoxetine inhibits CYP2D6, increasing haloperidol exposure. Additive QT prolongation.
Lithium augments serotonergic transmission. Common combination but requires monitoring.
Fluoxetine may inhibit diazepam metabolism. Additive CNS depression.
Serotonin syndrome risk from dual serotonergic activity. Sertraline moderately inhibits CYP2D6.
Paroxetine is strong CYP2D6 inhibitor. Blocks tramadol activation and increases serotonin syndrome risk.
Paroxetine strongly inhibits CYP2D6, preventing codeine to morphine conversion.
Serotonin syndrome risk from dual serotonergic activity.
Metronidazole inhibits CYP2C9, dramatically increasing warfarin levels. Major bleeding risk.
Fluconazole strongly inhibits CYP2C9/2C19. Major increase in warfarin effect.
Amiodarone inhibits CYP2C9/3A4. Increases warfarin levels 30-50%. Reduce warfarin dose.
Additive anticoagulant/antiplatelet effect. Major GI and intracranial bleeding risk.
NSAIDs increase bleeding risk and may inhibit warfarin metabolism. GI bleeding risk.
NSAID + anticoagulant. Major bleeding risk.
Ciprofloxacin inhibits CYP1A2 and may increase warfarin effect.
Clarithromycin inhibits CYP3A4 and may increase S-warfarin levels.
Complex bidirectional interaction via CYP2C9 and protein binding displacement.
Carbamazepine induces CYP enzymes, potentially reducing warfarin effect.
Ketoconazole strongly inhibits CYP3A4. Massive increase in simvastatin levels. Rhabdomyolysis risk.
Clarithromycin strongly inhibits CYP3A4. Simvastatin levels increase dramatically. Rhabdomyolysis risk.
Cyclosporine inhibits CYP3A4 and P-gp. Extreme statin level increase. Rhabdomyolysis.
Amiodarone inhibits CYP3A4. Simvastatin dose must not exceed 20mg. Rhabdomyolysis risk.
Diltiazem inhibits CYP3A4. Simvastatin dose should not exceed 10mg.
Verapamil inhibits CYP3A4. Simvastatin dose should not exceed 10mg.
Ketoconazole strongly inhibits CYP3A4. Major increase in atorvastatin exposure.
Clarithromycin inhibits CYP3A4. Increased atorvastatin levels.
Cyclosporine inhibits CYP3A4 and OATP1B1. Major increase in atorvastatin levels.
Omeprazole inhibits CYP2C19, reducing clopidogrel activation. Diminished antiplatelet effect.
Dual antiplatelet therapy. Increased bleeding risk but commonly used intentionally post-ACS.
NSAIDs increase bleeding risk when combined with antiplatelet agents.
Additive bleeding risk with NSAID and antiplatelet.
Amiodarone inhibits P-gp, increasing digoxin levels 70-100%. Reduce digoxin dose by 50%.
Amiodarone inhibits CYP2C9, increasing phenytoin levels. Phenytoin may also reduce amiodarone.
Additive QT prolongation. Risk of torsades de pointes.
Additive QT prolongation. Significant risk of torsades de pointes.
Additive QT prolongation from both agents.
Amiodarone inhibits CYP2D6, increasing metoprolol levels. Additive bradycardia risk.
Amiodarone inhibits CYP3A4 and P-gp, increasing cyclosporine levels.
Ciprofloxacin strongly inhibits CYP1A2, causing dangerous theophylline accumulation. Seizure risk.
Additive nephrotoxicity risk.
Ciprofloxacin may decrease methotrexate renal clearance.
Additive QT prolongation risk.
Additive QT prolongation risk.
Clarithromycin inhibits P-gp and kills gut flora that metabolize digoxin. Major level increase.
Clarithromycin inhibits CYP3A4 and P-gp, significantly increasing cyclosporine exposure.
Clarithromycin inhibits CYP3A4. Major increase in quetiapine levels causing excessive sedation.
Clarithromycin inhibits CYP3A4 metabolism of carbamazepine. Toxicity risk.
Clarithromycin inhibits CYP3A4, increasing fentanyl levels. Respiratory depression risk.
Ketoconazole strongly inhibits CYP3A4 and P-gp. Major cyclosporine level increase.
Ketoconazole strongly inhibits CYP3A4. Quetiapine levels increase dramatically.
Ketoconazole inhibits CYP3A4 fentanyl metabolism. Risk of respiratory depression.
Ketoconazole inhibits CYP3A4. Major increase in alprazolam levels and CNS depression.
Bidirectional CYP3A4 inhibition. Increased levels of both drugs.
Fluconazole inhibits CYP2C9/2C19, increasing phenytoin levels. Toxicity risk.
Fluconazole inhibits CYP3A4 and CYP2C9. Increased rhabdomyolysis risk with simvastatin.
Fluconazole inhibits CYP2C9, increasing glipizide levels. Hypoglycemia risk.
Fluconazole inhibits carbamazepine metabolism.
Verapamil inhibits P-gp, increasing digoxin levels. Additive AV nodal depression.
Diltiazem increases digoxin levels via P-gp inhibition. Additive bradycardia.
Cyclosporine inhibits P-gp, increasing digoxin exposure.
Spironolactone may increase digoxin levels and alter electrolytes affecting digoxin sensitivity.
Furosemide-induced hypokalemia increases digoxin toxicity risk.
Thiazide-induced hypokalemia increases digoxin toxicity risk.
NSAIDs reduce renal lithium clearance. Can increase lithium levels 15-50%.
NSAIDs reduce renal lithium clearance.
ACE inhibitors reduce lithium renal clearance. Levels may increase significantly.
ARBs may reduce lithium renal clearance, though generally less than ACE inhibitors.
Loop diuretics cause sodium depletion increasing lithium reabsorption. Toxicity risk.
Thiazide diuretics reduce lithium clearance by 25%. Common cause of lithium toxicity.
Additive neurotoxicity risk. Both lower seizure threshold.
Mutual enzyme induction. Unpredictable effects on levels of both drugs.
Carbamazepine reduces valproate levels via CYP induction. Valproate may increase carbamazepine-epoxide.
Carbamazepine induces doxycycline metabolism, potentially reducing its half-life by 50%.
Carbamazepine induces CYP3A4, dramatically reducing quetiapine levels.
Valproate displaces phenytoin from protein binding and inhibits its metabolism. Complex interaction.
Phenytoin induces theophylline metabolism, reducing its levels.
Phenytoin induces CYP3A4, dramatically reducing cyclosporine levels. Transplant rejection risk.
Phenytoin may reduce doxycycline efficacy through enzyme induction.
NSAIDs reduce methotrexate renal clearance. Risk of methotrexate toxicity including pancytopenia.
NSAIDs reduce methotrexate renal clearance.
PPIs may reduce methotrexate renal elimination, increasing levels.
Ciprofloxacin may decrease renal tubular transport of methotrexate.
Additive immunosuppression and nephrotoxicity.
Listed above but bidirectional entry. Rhabdomyolysis risk.
Diltiazem inhibits CYP3A4, increasing cyclosporine levels.
Verapamil inhibits CYP3A4 and P-gp, increasing cyclosporine levels.
Both increase potassium retention. Hyperkalemia risk especially with renal impairment.
Dual RAAS blockade. Increased risk of hyperkalemia, hypotension, and renal failure. Generally avoided.
NSAIDs reduce antihypertensive effect and increase renal and hyperkalemia risk.
NSAIDs reduce ACE inhibitor efficacy and increase renal risk.
Low-dose aspirin: minimal effect. High-dose aspirin may reduce ACE inhibitor efficacy.
Both retain potassium. Significant hyperkalemia risk.
NSAIDs may impair renal function, reducing metformin clearance. Minor at normal doses.
Furosemide may increase metformin levels. Minor clinical significance.
Ciprofloxacin may alter blood glucose and affect metformin clearance.
Metronidazole inhibits CYP2C9, potentially increasing glipizide levels and hypoglycemia risk.
Fluconazole inhibits CYP2C9, increasing glipizide levels.
Additive CNS depression. Tramadol adds serotonergic risk to opioid combination.
Combined CNS depression risk. Respiratory depression. Tramadol lowers seizure threshold.
Opioid-benzodiazepine combination. FDA boxed warning for respiratory depression.
FDA boxed warning: opioid + benzodiazepine. Respiratory depression, coma, death risk.
FDA boxed warning: opioid + benzodiazepine combination.
FDA boxed warning: opioid + benzodiazepine combination.
FDA boxed warning: opioid + benzodiazepine combination.
Opioid + benzodiazepine. Respiratory depression risk.
Additive QT prolongation from both agents.
Risk of neurotoxicity and NMS-like syndrome. Monitor neurological status.
Additive sedation and orthostatic hypotension.
Phenytoin induces CYP3A4, reducing quetiapine levels. May need dose increase.
Both agents depress cardiac conduction. Risk of severe bradycardia, AV block, heart failure.
Non-dihydropyridine CCB + beta-blocker. Severe bradycardia and conduction abnormalities.
Verapamil increases digoxin levels 50-75%. Additive AV nodal depression.
Diltiazem inhibits CYP3A4. Simvastatin dose should not exceed 10mg.
Verapamil inhibits CYP3A4. Simvastatin dose should not exceed 10mg.
Spironolactone may interfere with digoxin assay and alter K+ balance.
First-dose hypotension with ACE inhibitor + diuretic. Common but monitor.
Intentional combination (Zestoretic). Additive hypotension. Generally well tolerated.
Intentional combination (Hyzaar). Additive antihypertensive effect.
PPIs raise gastric pH, reducing levothyroxine absorption. May need dose adjustment.
Carbamazepine induces levothyroxine metabolism, potentially causing hypothyroidism.
Phenytoin displaces levothyroxine from binding proteins and induces its metabolism.
Corticosteroid + NSAID increases GI ulceration and bleeding risk.
Corticosteroid + NSAID increases GI ulceration and bleeding risk.
Corticosteroid + NSAID. Additive GI bleeding risk.
Prednisone may enhance or diminish warfarin effect. GI bleeding risk.
Corticosteroids increase blood glucose, opposing metformin effect.
Corticosteroids increase blood glucose, opposing glipizide effect.
Clarithromycin inhibits CYP3A4, modestly increasing theophylline levels.
Carbamazepine induces theophylline metabolism.
Amlodipine modestly inhibits CYP3A4. Simvastatin dose should not exceed 20mg.
Ketoconazole strongly inhibits CYP3A4 and P-gp, dramatically increasing rivaroxaban levels.
Clarithromycin inhibits CYP3A4 and P-gp, increasing rivaroxaban levels and bleeding risk.
Additive bleeding risk. Sometimes used intentionally in ACS.
NSAID + DOAC. Significant bleeding risk.
NSAID + DOAC. Significant bleeding risk.
Additive CNS depression and sedation. Monitor for excessive sedation.
Aspirin displaces valproate from protein binding, increasing free fraction.
Aspirin reduces methotrexate renal clearance and displaces from protein binding.
Duplicate of lisinopril+spironolactone for bidirectional lookup.
Duplicate for bidirectional lookup.
No clinically significant interaction. Commonly co-prescribed safely in diabetic hypertensive patients.
No significant interaction. Different pathways.
No significant interaction. Beta-blockers may mask hypoglycemia symptoms but this is minor.
No clinically significant interaction.
No significant interaction. Very commonly co-prescribed.
No significant interaction. Commonly co-prescribed.
Intentional combination for hypertension. Complementary mechanisms. No adverse interaction.
Commonly co-prescribed for heart failure and hypertension. Additive benefit.
No significant interaction. Common cardiovascular combination.
Bidirectional entry. No significant interaction.
Combined as Caduet. No clinically significant interaction.
Commonly co-prescribed. Dihydropyridine CCB + beta-blocker is safe unlike non-dihydropyridine.
Commonly co-prescribed for hypertension. No adverse interaction.
No significant interaction.
No significant interaction.
No significant interaction.
No significant interaction. Different elimination pathways.
No significant interaction.
No significant interaction.
No significant interaction. No CYP involvement for gabapentin.
No significant interaction.
Commonly co-prescribed for hypertension and heart failure.
No significant interaction. Standard cardiovascular co-prescription.
No significant interaction. Complementary antihypertensive mechanisms.
No clinically significant interaction at usual doses.
No significant interaction.
Additive antihypertensive effect but no adverse interaction.
Commonly co-prescribed. No adverse interaction.
No significant interaction.
No significant interaction.
No significant interaction.
No clinically significant interaction.
No significant interaction. Omeprazole sometimes given prophylactically with steroids.
No significant interaction.
No significant interaction. Commonly co-prescribed.
No significant interaction.
No significant interaction.
No clinically significant interaction.
No significant interaction.
No significant pharmacokinetic interaction. Fluoxetine may slightly improve insulin sensitivity.
No clinically significant interaction.
No significant interaction at standard doses.
No significant interaction. Commonly co-prescribed in cardiovascular patients.
No significant interaction. Standard cardiovascular prevention regimen.
No significant interaction. Commonly co-prescribed.
Duplicate entry for bidirectional lookup.
No significant interaction.
No significant interaction.
No significant interaction.
Dual opioid agonism. Additive respiratory depression.
Additive opioid effects. Codeine converts to morphine.
Anticoagulant + antiplatelet. Major bleeding risk. Triple therapy concern.
Dual anticoagulation. No indication. Extreme bleeding risk.
No significant interaction. Different elimination pathways.
No significant interaction.
No significant interaction.
No significant interaction. Commonly co-prescribed.
No significant interaction.
No significant interaction.
No significant interaction.
No clinically significant interaction.
